advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href=§http://www.sbrowning.com/vintage§>Steve Browning, www.sbrowning.com/vintage</a>.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1980 COLECO CATALOG</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.textfiles.com/digitize/items/" target="_blank">Digitize, Textfiles.com</a> for the picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> F.D. UNIT ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>BBC floppy disc unit was delivered with a 8271 FD controller chip and a Filing System software in ROM to be fitted into the BBC system.<br> Two versions of F.D. units were available:<br> - A single drive unit, single side, single density, 100 KB space.<br> - A dual drive version, double side, double density, 800 KB space. <p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>8BS.com</b> </p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> BRAZILIAN ADVERT (1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.mci.org.br" target="_blank">Museu da Computação e Informática - MCI</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT (APRIL 1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <http://www.classiccmp.org/dunfield/miscpm/" target="_blank">Dave Dunfield</a> for the picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><i>A computer, which grows with your requirements</i> <p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Joscelyn Flores</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ACORN AD #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><font color="#666666"> Success in the future will depend upon confidence in using new technologies. That's why a computer in the home has to be more than just an interesting diversion or even a useful tool. It has to an investment in tomorrow for you and your children... </font> <p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>8bs.com</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> DEMO TAPE INLAY #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.primo.homeserver.hu/" target="_blank">PRIMO home-page</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PLUS3 ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><font color="#666666"> The Plus 3 is a self contained disc interface and 3.5 single sized disc drive providing the user with over 300 Kbytes of storage and the new powerful advanced Disc Filing System (ADFS). ADFS provides easy to use facilities at the Basic level but also has features making it ideal for business use...<br> ...A second expansion socket on the Plus 3 allows the connection of a further disc drive, this can be either 3.5 inch or 5.25 inch. </font><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>8bs.com</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST SDK-85 AD</strong></font><br><blockquote>Notice the Intel logo. Does Intel copies the Apple logo or vice versa?</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US AD. MAY 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> Before you start hunting from store to store for the ideal microcomputer, consider this: You won't find it.<br> That's because the world's most versatile micro is available only from the manufacturer. It's Lobo MAX-80 And, dollar for dollar, feature for feature, there isn't another system that even comes close....</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> AMIGAWORLD PREVIEW</strong></font><br><blockquote>Thanks to Jun Suzuki <a href="http://member.nifty.ne.jp/tarucus/museum/cool/cool.htm">web site</a></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1978 BROCHURE #14</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>November 1987<br><br><font color="#666666"> ...This elegant little machine takes family computing into new dimensions of creativity, excitement and productivity. It outruns and outguns office PCs as a business multi-tasker, performing a deskful of different jobs simultaneously at over 7 million steps per second in realtime... </font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> COMMERCIAL PAMPHLET - PAGE #3</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">thanks to Richard Rogers </p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ORIGINAL ARTICLE</strong></font><br><blockquote>The history of the Galaksija started with a magazine article - called "Raèunara u vašoj kuæi" (computers in your home) by Dejan Ristanoviæ. This magazine was the first issue of the magazine series called later "Raèunara". This first issue included an article about the do-if-yourself computer "Galaksija" written by Voja Antonic. <br><br> <font color="#666666">Source : <a href="http://www.homecomputer.de/" target="_blank">HomeComputerMuseum.de</a></font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>''The sound, the color, the intelligence''</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT (NOV. 1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says:<br><br> The Acorn Atom is a definitive personal computer. Simple to build, simple to operate. A powerful, full facility computer with all the features you would expect.<br> Just connect the assembled computer to any domestic TV and power source and you are ready to begin. (Power requirement: 8V at 800mA). There is an ATOM power unit available. <br><br> Free with every ATOM, kit or built, is a computer manual. The first section explains and teaches you BASIC, the language that most personal computers and the ATOM operate in. The instructions are simple and learning quickly becomes a pleasure. You'll soon be writing your own programs. The second section is a reference manual giving a full description of the ATOM's facilities and how to use them. Both sections arE fully illustrated with example programs. <br><br> <b>The standard ATOM includes:</b><br> HARDWARE<br> . Full-sized QWERTY keyboard. 6502 Microprocessor. Rugged injection-moulded case. 2K RAM. 8K HYPER-ROM<br> . 23 integrated circuits and sockets. Audio cassette interface. UHF TV output. Full assembly instructions<br> SOFTWARE<br> . 32-bit arithmetic (:i: 2,000,000,000). High speed execution. 43 standard/extended BASIC commands. Variable length strings (up to 256 characters) . String manipulation functions. 27 x 32 bit integer variables<br> . 27 additional arrays. Random number function. PUT and GET byte. WAIT command for timing. DO-UNTIL construction . Logical operators (AND, OR, EX-OR) . Link t machine - code routines. PLOT commands, DRAW and MOVE <br><br> <b>The ATOM modular concept</b><br> The ATOM has been designed to grow with you. As you build confidence and knowledge you can add more components. For instance the next stage might be to increase the ROM and RAM on the basic ATOM from 8K + 2K to 12K + 12K respectively. This will give you a direct printer drive, floating point mathematics, scientific and trigonometric functions, high resolution graphics.<br> From there you can expand indefinitely. Acorn have produced an enormous range of compatible PCB's which can be added to your original computer. For instance: A module to give red, green and blue colour signals Teletext VDU card (for Prestel and Ceefax information) An in-board connector for a communications loop interface - any number of ATOMs may be linked to each other or to a master system with mass storage/hard copy facility. <p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Paul Durrant</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Gerard Touitou</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>UK advert from Personal Computer World magazine, October 1983</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROTOTYPE SOFTWARE</strong></font><br><blockquote>This picture from an early advert published in january 1983 is very interesting (the TO-7 was just released then). The text below it said "Hours of entertainment...". But when you look more carefully at the software boxes you realise that they are fake! Only the two extreme boxes are real, but still shows the same game title "3-D TIC-TAC TOE"! So there is only one game presented here! The photograph was surely taken at an early development stage... <br><br> Even the name of the computer written on top of the boxes: "TOM 7" (Tele Ordinateur Multimedia?) seems to be an early name for the TO-7... <br><br> Hours of entertainment they said...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL LEAFLET #3</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> LEAFLET (1982) - PAGE 2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Notice that the box arts are completely different from the final ones (see software section)</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN BROCHURE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Volken</b></p></blockquote>

computer.colors: 8 (each have normal and bright mode). Thanks to russian ULA, 96 colours multicolor support (like Russian Pentagon or Scorpion speccy clones)
computer.description:
The Didaktik Kompakt was the last model made by Didaktik Skalica.
The Didaktik Kompakt is a Didaktik M with a built-in 3.5" disk drive(720 KB). It has standard connectors for joysticks and printer and a built-in parallel interface using i8255 as in Didaktik Gama. The amount of internal ROM was doubled, 16 KB for the Spectrum BASIC interpreter and 16 KB for the MDOS operating system. All other features are the same as Didaktik M.
It was a real all-in-one computer with built-in power supply unit. Base model had 48 KB of RAM, expandable up to 128 KB (not provided by Didaktik). Sound output was a poor beeper. An AY 3-8912 sound shipset (3 voice, 8 octave + white noise generator) could be connected externaly via the Didaktik Melodik expansion.
Normal TV set could be used as well as EGA monitor. ULA custom chip was the same as the M version, screen was thus still square.
The interesting thing for computer collectors is you can still buy a didaktik model along with all its accessories and expansions. See Link section
_____________
Contributors: Vladimir Kopacek (info & pictures), Mikezt
computer.keyboard: QWERTY mechanical keyboard with separated arrow keys and many functions per key just like the spectrum
computer.media: 3,5'' 840 KB (DD) or 1.8 MB (HD). Standard PC floppy can be used
computer.name: Kompakt
computer.peripherals: I/O ports: 2 x 9-pin canon Sinclair and Kempston, TV and RGB output, conector for external FDD, expansion slot and 8255 interface
computer.ports: Expansion bus, Sinclair Joystick port, Kempston joystick port, RF TV video output, Composite video output (Monitor), SCART video & audio connector, Tape interface

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> TOP</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Krosik for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> REAR</strong></font><br><blockquote>From left to right:<br> <br> - expansion connector<br> - RF TV video output<br> - composite video output<br> - tape interface<br> - scart video connector<br> - on/off power switch<br> - power cord...<p class="petitgris">Thanks to Krosik for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> WITH BOX</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Krosik for this picture</p></blockquote>

computer.text: 32 x 22 or, 64 x 32 with special software
